CONVENTIONAL Lifetime Capacity.description: The lifetime capacity is the number of functional units (billion pass-km) that are generated by having one implementation unit (IUnit) for the entire period that the IUnit lasts. For Aviation, with an IUnit of available seat-km, the load factor tells us what the passenger-km is expected to be, and this is divided by 1 billion to get the required figure. Note that the time period is irrelevant as this is an ephemeral unit, and is hence equal to the average annual use. The IATA is the Global Airline body which must have the most accurate data, so only this source is used for the latest year available.

Discount Rate - Governments.description: The discount rates reported here are described as discount rates used for policy evaluation.  The rates reported are weighted by the relative % of GDP represented by the nation or region associated with the rate as reported with the idea that the majority of global investment will likely (at least for the early part of the Drawdown period of inquiry) by making the most sizzeable investments and a weighted discount rate is most relevant for evaluating the financial return potentials of those investments.  These values here, for the most part, discount the 'social welfare' discounting criteria used in some recommendations for discounting for policy (Stern value as an exception).  These values are mostly used for evaluating a more purely financial rationale more based in observable market behavior.  These rates are probably most relevant to be used for Drawdown solutions where government, state utilities, public agencies and policy making bodies are involved in the decision-making with regard to investments.  These values represent a conservative case and, due to uncertainty, and the werighted lower and higher discounting rates (low and high by one standard deviation) should probably be used for sensitivity analysis.
